awd_titl_txt: EAPSI:  Electron Emission and Ferroelectric Property Measurements of Dendritic Barium Titanate
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project was designed to test the ferroelectric properties of dendritic barium titanate for future use in areas such as FERAM and ferroelectric electron emitters. The dendrites were formed by hydrothermal conversion of a TiO2 nanowire template substrate in a 0.1M Ba(OH)2 solution at 200°C for up to 36 hours. This process resulted in a novel dentrite structure of barium titanate (BaTiO3 ) (Fig. 1). Analysis of the resulting structures using a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM), Electron Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS), and X-ray Diffraction (XRD) were performed prior to the start of this project. Although the structures were formed using techniques known to produce ferroelectric BaTiO3 structures such as these had not yet been reported in the literature so it was important to verify the material possessed the desired ferroelectric properties.

            To test the ferroelectric properties of the dendrites the samples were subjected to a sweeping voltage starting at 0V, increasing to some maximum voltage, deceased to a negative maximum voltage, and then returned to 0V. At each voltage step the polarization of the material, measured in coulombs per square meter (C/m2), was measured. This tye of measurement is known as a hysteresis loop measurement. As the voltage increases the polarization of the material should also increase to a maximum value, this is known as the maximum polarization. Upon returning the voltage to zero the polarization that remains is known as the remnant polarization and for applications such as FERAM, one would want this value to be near the maximum polarization. As the voltage is decreased past zero volts and down to the maximum negative voltage the maximum negative polarization is reached. In an ideal case, the maximum polarization occurs at the maximum applied voltage and is equal to the remnant polarization.

By applying the hysteresis loop type of measurement to the dendritic barium titanate we were able to directly measure the ferroelectric properties of the material. As can be seen in Figure 2, the material showed ferroelectric response to the applied voltage but had no remnant polarization. This indicates that this material is not suitable for applications such as FERAM. However, the hydrothermal process used to create the structures can often result in a range of final compositions. This means that not only can the BaTiO3 stoichiometry exist in this material, but so could other compounds which do not exhibit ferroelectric behavior and thus, could be reducing the ferroelectric behavior of the material as a whole. A simple way to set the stoichiometry is to anneal the samples at high temperature and allow them to cool. By doing so, the material has sufficient atomic mobility and time to relax into its room temperature state of BaTiO3. As such, we looked at the effects of sample annealing on the resulting hysteresis loop tests by annealing the for one hour samples at 500°C and 650°C and then subjecting them to ferroelectric testing. The results showed an improvement in both the maximum polarization and remnant polarization for each annealing treatment (Fig. 3) however, after the 500°C anneal significant losses in the measurement were seen. This may be attributed to the sample not having sufficient time to reorganize into the desired BaTiO3 structure.
